Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI is proposing to study problems which relate to both differential geometry and general relativity. The first project concerns the fundamental problems in asymptotically flat manifolds, particularly center of mass and constant mean curvature foliations. The PI has proved that the notion of Hamiltonian center of mass is well-defined in the time-slice and has constructed the constant mean curvature foliation whose geometric center is equal to the center of mass. The PI is proposing to further investigate the properties of center of mass in spacetime and the time evolution of center of mass and the foliation. The existence of constant mean curvature foliation is important for understanding the intrinsic geometry of asymptotically flat manifolds. The PI will continue to study the existence of the foliation even when the Hamiltonian center of mass might not be defined. In addition, a new density theorem previously developed by the PI shows that the solutions with harmonic asymptotics are generic in the space of solutions to the Einstein constraint equations. She intends to use the theorem to further study the physical quantities of the solutions, such as angular momentum. The second project deals with compact manifolds with boundary in various ambient spaces. The PI with Damin Wu developed the rigidity results on hemispheres for hypersurfaces with boundary in either Euclidean space or hyperbolic space. She plans to develop the analogous rigidity theorems for hypersurfaces with boundary in the sphere and for submanifolds in Euclidean space with higher codimensions under several different curvature conditions.

The PI's projects will lead to a better understanding of the physical quantities and their connection to geometry in asymptotically flat manifolds, which model the isolated systems in general relativity. In particular, the constant mean curvature foliation provides an intrinsic coordinate system for isolated systems. The foliation will be useful to understand the interaction of black holes in the problem of binary black holes which is fundamental in both theoretical and numerical physics. She also believes that the canonical coordinate system is helpful for numerists from different groups to compare their results established under different coordinate systems. The remainder of the PI's proposed work about compact regions with boundary naturally arises in general relativity and in various physical situations. It is fundamental to characterize and to classify the model cases, such as the flat regions and spheres. The rigidity results on these geometric objects are essential for the classification.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project consists two main goals: understanding the center of mass and angular momentum in general relativity and studying the scalar curvature rigidity. The research has immediate contribution to the mathematical community. The result on the Penrose inequality is the only result about the rigidity of the Penrose inequality that holds in all dimensions. Our argument is adapted by other mathematicians in different settings and has applications to another field such as the study of mean curvature flows. For example, it is showed that nonnegative scalar curvature is preserved by the mean curvature flow. Another key result of the project confirms the conjectures of the ADM mass and momentum inequalities and advances our knowledge about the global conserved quantities. The PI and her collaborators develop new tools to study marginally outer trapper surfaces which have applications in the study of black holes in general relativity. The developed density theorems provide deeper understanding to the structure of the Einstein constraint equations. The result has brought several wide applications within the field of geometric analysis, but it should provide long-term benefits to the mathematics and physics community.

The PI also believes that her research supported by NSF will have long time benefits to sciences, in particular in promoting education in science.  She makes every effort to promote general relativity to broader audiences. The PI gave a series of lectures at MSRI in the Summer Graduate Workshop in Mathematical General Relativity in 2012. In one of the five lectures, the results funded by this award, accompanying by visually attractive examples, introduced students to some of the most fundemental theorems in general relativity (in a specialized setting). A draft of the lecture notes is posted on the MSRI webpage. The videos of the lecture series are also available to the public. Because the success of this workshop, a similar summer graduate school was held in August 2013 in Cortona, Italy. Both students from the US and Europe attended. The PI discussed the center of mass in general relativity from the geometric and analytic point of view. In particular, some recent results in the first part of the project on specifying the center of mass and angular momentum were discussed. Several graduate students became interested in pursuing further in this field.

The PI co­organized a special semester-long event in differential geomtery at University of Connecticut in Fall 2013, which was aimed at students and faculty of all fields. The event consists of introductory lecture series for students, the Distinguished Lecture Series, and colloquia. Two introductory lectures were given to graduate students in math, but it also drew a great attendance of students from the Physics department because general relativity is a topic that attracts people from many fields. The Distinguished Lecture Series was given by a world-leading expert Prof. Richard Schoen on important recent developments in differential geometry. Some of the results of this awarded project were presented in the lecture series. The talks attracted more than 400 participants in total. Among them, there were undergraduate students, graduate students, and faculty in a wide range of disciplines including math, physics, statistics, and arts at University of Connecticut. Furthermore, many professors and graduate students came from other universities in New England, such as MIT, Brown, UMass Amherst, and Central Connecticut State. This event at University of Connecticut was one of the most significant events in differential geometry in New England this year and should attract more students into math and sciences in the long term.
